articles.headline: For Big Drug Companies, a Headache Looms
articles.snippet: Going against a decade of rulings, a federal appeals court said payments aimed at holding back generics were anticompetitive, setting up possible review by the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Going against a decade of rulings, a federal appeals court said payments aimed at holding back generics were anticompetitive, setting up possible review by the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It would seem a business executive’s dream: legally pay a competitor to keep its product off the market for years.

articles.headline: Bollywood Star Remakes Himself Into TV Conscience
articles.snippet: Mixing Oprah-style interviews on a couch with short reports from the field, Aamir Khan’s show shines a spotlight on social issues like dowries, domestic violence and the caste system.
articles.abstract: Mixing Oprah-style interviews on a couch with short reports from the field, Aamir Khan’s show shines a spotlight on social issues like dowries, domestic violence and the caste system.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Aamir Khan spent more than two decades as one of India’s most admired movie stars, appearing in a string of socially conscious but mainstream films.

articles.headline: Facebook Delivers an Earnings Letdown
articles.snippet: Investors fled the stock in droves even as Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, extolled its growth prospects to industry analysts.
articles.abstract: Investors fled the stock in droves even as Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, extolled its growth prospects to industry analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Unhappy with Facebook’s first financial report as a public company Thursday, investors fled the stock in droves even as Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, extolled its growth prospects to industry analysts.

articles.headline: Scandals May Cost the Banks Their Clout
articles.snippet: Banks recovered their self-confidence and influence quickly after the financial crisis. But they may fare worse after JPMorgan Chase’s hedging losses and the Libor scandal.
articles.abstract: Banks recovered their self-confidence and influence quickly after the financial crisis. But they may fare worse after JPMorgan Chase’s hedging losses and the Libor scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the financial crisis, nothing was more surprising than the speed with which the banks regained their self-confidence and their influence, not to mention their haughtiness.

articles.headline: Cocaine’s Flow Is Unchecked in Venezuela
articles.snippet: Venezuela’s government has trumpeted one major blow after another against drug traffickers, but a visit to its remote western plains shows that its claims are greatly overstated.
articles.abstract: Venezuela’s government has trumpeted one major blow after another against drug traffickers, but a visit to its remote western plains shows that its claims are greatly overstated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA MACANILLA, Venezuela — The Venezuelan government has trumpeted one major blow after another against drug traffickers, showing off barrels of liquid cocaine seized, drug planes recovered, cocaine labs raided and airstrips destroyed.

articles.headline: Once a Rebel, McCain Now Walks the Party Line
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain of Arizona appears to have entered Version 3 of his long and multipronged career in the upper chamber — partisan warrior and party stalwart.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain of Arizona appears to have entered Version 3 of his long and multipronged career in the upper chamber — partisan warrior and party stalwart.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Election Day edges close and most members of Congress yearn to flee Washington, Senator John McCain of Arizona is more present than ever.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Falls to 1.5%; a Recovery Seems Mired
articles.snippet: Growth in the second quarter was held back as consumers curbed purchases and factories received fewer orders in the face of a global slowdown and a stronger dollar.
articles.abstract: Growth in the second quarter was held back as consumers curbed purchases and factories received fewer orders in the face of a global slowdown and a stronger dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy has lost the momentum it appeared to be building earlier this year, as the latest government statistics showed that it expanded by a mere 1.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
